questions.text: A patient presents with the following laboratory values: Which of the following best describes the patient’s acid–base status?

options.label: B
options.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis

options.label: C
options.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

questions.correct_answer: C. Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Anion gap metabolic acidosis: Does not account for the extra bicarbonate drop.
  • • Option A. Anion gap metabolic acidosis:
  • • Option B. Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis: Would typically yield a higher bicarbonate, often with Δ–Δ > 2.
  • • Option B. Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis:
  • • Option D. Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis: The elevated AG of 18 rules out a pure normal AG acidosis.
  • • Option D. Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When you see a low bicarbonate and an elevated anion gap, use the Delta–Delta Ratio. A ratio <1 suggests coexisting anion gap and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Top of Form

questions.text: A patient has the following laboratory findings: Which of the following is the most likely acid–base status

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation

questions.correct_answer: D. Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Acute respiratory acidosis would present with a low pH (acidemia) and high PCO₂, not alkalemia.
  • • Option A. Acute respiratory acidosis
  • • Option B. Acute respiratory alkalosis would show a high pH but a low PCO₂.
  • • Option B. Acute respiratory alkalosis
  • • Option C. Chronic respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation typically results in a less elevated pH; 7.55 is too alkalotic for that scenario.
  • • Option C. Chronic respiratory acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A high bicarbonate and alkalemic pH accompanied by an elevated, appropriately compensated PCO₂ is characteristic of metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with chronic liver disease is admitted for worsening abdominal distension. His laboratory findings are as follows: Sodium (Na⁺): 140 mEq/L Chloride (Cl⁻): 115 mEq/L Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻): 26 mEq/L Albumin: 1.2 g/dL Which of the following best explains the anion gap?

options.label: B
options.text: Hypoalbuminemia leading to a reduction in the anion gap

options.label: C
options.text: Unmeasured cation excess due to multiple myeloma

questions.correct_answer: B. Hypoalbuminemia leading to a reduction in the anion gap
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypoalbuminemia leading to a reduction in the anion gap

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Laboratory error in chloride measurement is unlikely because the sodium, chloride, and bicarbonate levels are consistent with normal measurement trends.
  • • Option A. Laboratory error in chloride measurement
  • • Option C. Unmeasured cation excess due to multiple myeloma can reduce the anion gap through excess cationic monoclonal proteins, but this patient has no evidence of multiple myeloma, and hypoalbuminemia is a more likely explanation.
  • • Option C. Unmeasured cation excess due to multiple myeloma
  • • Option D. Metabolic alkalosis does not typically result in a low anion gap. It may raise bicarbonate, but that does not account for the reduction in the anion gap observed here.
  • • Option D. Metabolic alkalosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anion gap is significantly influenced by albumin levels. Hypoalbuminemia decreases the anion gap by reducing unmeasured anions. In this case, the corrected anion gap appropriately accounts for the low albumin, ruling out other causes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with fever and altered mental status. On examination, his blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg and his pulse rate is 134/min. He has crackles over the left infrascapular region. Lab results are as follows: Na⁺: 138 mEq/L, Cl⁻: 98 mEq/L, HCO₃⁻: 10 mEq/L, BUN: 58 mg/dL, Creatinine: 3.0 mg/dL, Blood glucose: 180 mg/dL. Which of the following best explains the anion gap?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Accumulation of lactate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Excessive administration of normal saline: Causes a normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) acidosis, not an elevated one.
  • • Option A. Excessive administration of normal saline:
  • • Option B. Ketone body production: Are less likely because the glucose of 180 mg/dL is not highly suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis, and the clinical picture points more toward sepsis.
  • • Option B. Ketone body production:
  • • Option C. Hyperchloremia: Results in Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis
  • • Option C. Hyperchloremia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a hypotensive, septic patient, a high anion gap metabolic acidosis most often indicates lactic acidosis secondary to poor tissue perfusion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with hypokalemia and recurrent kidney stones presents with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. His urinary anion gap is measured and found to be positive. Which of the following best explains this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Low NH₄⁺ excretion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Excess NH₄⁺ excretion : Would cause a negative urinary anion gap, more typical of GI bicarbonate loss rather than a renal defect.
  • • Option A. Excess NH₄⁺ excretion
  • • negative
  • • Option C. High urinary chloride: Alone does not necessarily produce a positive urinary anion gap; in fact, increased urinary chloride often makes the gap more negative or closer to zero.
  • • Option C. High urinary chloride:
  • • positive
  • • Option D. Excessive urinary acidification : Is not consistent with a positive urinary anion gap; with adequate NH₄⁺ excretion and acidification, the gap would be negative.
  • • Option D. Excessive urinary acidification
  • • positive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A positive urinary anion gap in a patient with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis typically indicates low NH₄⁺ excretion and points to a renal rather than GI cause of the acidosis (e.g., distal RTA).
  • ➤ positive
  • ➤ low NH₄⁺ excretion
  • ➤ renal
  • ➤ GI

questions.text: A patient has the following laboratory findings: Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?

options.label: C
options.text: Acute respiratory acidosis plus acute metabolic acidosis

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chronic respiratory acidosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Acute metabolic acidosis : Incorrect because metabolic acidosis would present with a low bicarbonate and compensatory low PCO₂, not elevated PCO₂.
  • • Option A. Acute metabolic acidosis
  • • Option B. Acute respiratory acidosis : Incorrect because bicarbonate is elevated, indicating renal compensation, which occurs only in chronic conditions.
  • • Option B. Acute respiratory acidosis
  • • Option C. Acute respiratory acidosis plus acute metabolic acidosis : Incorrect because the elevated bicarbonate rules out a primary metabolic acidosis.
  • • Option C. Acute respiratory acidosis plus acute metabolic acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic respiratory acidosis occurs with prolonged CO₂ retention, leading to renal compensation by increasing bicarbonate. Differentiating acute from chronic respiratory acidosis requires assessing bicarbonate levels, which increase significantly only in chronic conditions.

questions.text: A patient has the following laboratory findings: Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?

options.label: B
options.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis

options.label: C
options.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anion gap metabolic acidosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Anion gap metabolic acidosis : Plus metabolic alkalosis is incorrect because there is no elevated bicarbonate or evidence of alkalosis.
  • • Option B. Anion gap metabolic acidosis
  • • Option C. Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis: Is incorrect as there is no hyperchloremia to suggest an additional non-anion gap acidosis.
  • • Option C. Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis:
  • • Option D. Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis : Is incorrect as the elevated anion gap clearly indicates an anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • • Option D. Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delta-delta ratio analysis helps differentiate pure anion gap metabolic acidosis from mixed acid-base disorders. A ratio within the normal range (1–2) confirms a single anion gap metabolic acidosis without additional acid-base disturbances.

questions.text: A patient has the following laboratory findings: Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?

options.label: C
options.text: Metabolic acidosis plus primary respiratory alkalosis

options.label: D
options.text: Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation

questions.correct_answer: C. Metabolic acidosis plus primary respiratory alkalosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Metabolic acidosis plus primary respiratory alkalosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Acute respiratory acidosis : Is incorrect because the PCO₂ is low, not elevated, ruling out respiratory acidosis.
  • • Option A. Acute respiratory acidosis
  • • Option B. Chronic respiratory acidosis : Is incorrect because the bicarbonate would be elevated due to renal compensation, not reduced.
  • • Option B. Chronic respiratory acidosis
  • • Option D. Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation : Is incorrect because the PCO₂ is lower than the expected range, indicating an additional primary respiratory alkalosis.
  • • Option D. Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The delta ratio and Winter’s formula are essential tools for evaluating mixed acid-base disorders. A PCO₂ lower than expected in metabolic acidosis suggests an additional respiratory alkalosis. This highlights the importance of calculating expected compensation to detect hidden mixed disorders.

questions.text: A patient has the following laboratory findings: Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?

options.label: C
options.text: Acute respiratory acidosis plus acute metabolic acidosis

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute respiratory acidosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Acute metabolic acidosis : Incorrect because metabolic acidosis would present with low bicarbonate and compensatory low PCO₂, which are not observed here.
  • • Option A. Acute metabolic acidosis
  • • Option C. Acute respiratory acidosis plus acute metabolic acidosis : Incorrect because the bicarbonate is normal, ruling out metabolic acidosis.
  • • Option C. Acute respiratory acidosis plus acute metabolic acidosis
  • • Option D. Chronic metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation : Incorrect because chronic metabolic acidosis would present with low bicarbonate and low PCO₂ as compensation.
  • • Option D. Chronic metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute respiratory acidosis is characterized by an acidemic pH, elevated PCO₂, and normal bicarbonate (before compensation occurs). Compensation for respiratory acidosis takes days, so normal bicarbonate suggests an acute process.

questions.text: A patient has the following laboratory findings: Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?

options.label: C
options.text: Acute respiratory alkalosis plus acute metabolic alkalosis

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation

questions.correct_answer: D. Chronic respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chronic respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Acute metabolic acidosis : Incorrect, as acidosis would result in a low pH, not the alkalotic pH seen here.
  • • Option A. Acute metabolic acidosis
  • • Option B. Acute respiratory alkalosis : Incorrect because bicarbonate levels are reduced, indicating renal compensation, which occurs only in chronic conditions.
  • • Option B. Acute respiratory alkalosis
  • • Option C. Acute respiratory alkalosis plus acute metabolic alkalosis : Incorrect because the bicarbonate is low, ruling out metabolic alkalosis.
  • • Option C. Acute respiratory alkalosis plus acute metabolic alkalosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic respiratory alkalosis occurs with prolonged hyperventilation, leading to renal compensation by reducing bicarbonate levels. The distinction between acute and chronic respiratory alkalosis is based on bicarbonate levels, which decrease significantly only in chronic conditions.

questions.text: A patient has the following laboratory findings: Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?

options.label: B
options.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis

options.label: C
options.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Anion gap metabolic acidosis: This is partially correct but incomplete as it doesn't account for the mixed disorder indicated by the delta ratio > 2.
  • • Option A
  • • Option C . Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis: Incorrect because the delta ratio > 2 indicates alkalosis, not a second acidosis. In mixed normal gap and high gap acidosis, the delta ratio would be < 1.
  • • Option C
  • • Option D . Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis: Clearly incorrect as the AG is significantly elevated at 40.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Use the delta ratio to identify mixed acid-base disorders. A delta ratio > 2 suggests concurrent metabolic alkalosis along with anion gap metabolic acidosis, which can occur in conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis with vomiting or lactic acidosis with diuretic use.

questions.text: A patient has the following laboratory findings: Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?

options.label: C
options.text: Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation

options.label: D
options.text: Mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis

questions.correct_answer: D. Mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Acute respiratory acidosis: The low bicarbonate and pH indicate metabolic involvement, which excludes isolated acute respiratory acidosis.
  • • Option A. Acute respiratory acidosis:
  • • Option B. Chronic respiratory acidosis: Chronic conditions show higher bicarbonate compensation, which is not present here.
  • • Option B. Chronic respiratory acidosis:
  • • Option C. Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: The observed PCO₂ is much higher than predicted by Winter's formula, ruling out appropriate compensation.
  • • Option C. Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Winter's formula is a crucial tool to differentiate between simple and mixed acid-base disorders in metabolic acidosis. A discrepancy between observed and expected PCO₂ indicates an additional respiratory process.

questions.text: A patient has the following laboratory findings: Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻): 32 mEq/L pH: 7.51 PCO₂: 35 mm Hg Which of the following best describes the patient's acid-base status?
questions.correct_answer: D. Metabolic alkalosis plus respiratory alkalosis
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The pH of 7.51 indicates alkalemia (alkalotic state). The elevated bicarbonate (>24 mEq/L) signifies a primary metabolic alkalosis. In metabolic alkalosis, the respiratory system typically compensates by increasing
  • • The pH of 7.51 indicates alkalemia (alkalotic state).
  • • The elevated bicarbonate (>24 mEq/L) signifies a primary metabolic alkalosis.
  • • In metabolic alkalosis, the respiratory system typically compensates by increasing
  • • PCO₂ to help normalize pH. But here the PCO₂ is 35 mm Hg (<40), which is low indicating an independent respiratory alkalosis as well.
  • • Whenever HCO₃⁻ (high in this case) and PCO2 (low in this case), move in opposite directions it is highly suggestive of a mixed disorder.
  • • Whenever HCO₃⁻ (high in this case) and PCO2 (low in this case), move in opposite directions it is highly suggestive of a mixed disorder.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Chronic respiratory alkalosis : Usually presents with decreased PCO₂ and a compensatory decrease in bicarbonate (not elevated). The elevated bicarbonate here rules this out. Option B. Acute respiratory alkalosis : Typically involves decreased PCO₂ with normal bicarbonate and an elevated pH. Since bicarbonate is grossly elevated here, this does not fit. Option C. Metabolic alkalosis plus respiratory acidosis : Respiratory acidosis involves elevated PCO₂, but here PCO₂ is low, so this is incorrect.
  • • Option A. Chronic respiratory alkalosis : Usually presents with decreased PCO₂ and a compensatory decrease in bicarbonate (not elevated). The elevated bicarbonate here rules this out.
  • • Option A. Chronic respiratory alkalosis
  • • Option B. Acute respiratory alkalosis : Typically involves decreased PCO₂ with normal bicarbonate and an elevated pH. Since bicarbonate is grossly elevated here, this does not fit.
  • • Option B. Acute respiratory alkalosis
  • • Option C. Metabolic alkalosis plus respiratory acidosis : Respiratory acidosis involves elevated PCO₂, but here PCO₂ is low, so this is incorrect.
  • • Option C. Metabolic alkalosis plus respiratory acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When HCO₃⁻ and PCO₂ move in opposite directions—it indicates a mixed acid-base disorder.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with severe metabolic acidosis and the following lab results: Sodium: 140 mEq/L Chloride: 100 mEq/L Bicarbonate: 8 mEq/L BUN: 56 mg/dL Plasma Glucose: 180 mg/dL Serum Osmolality: 332 mOsm/kg Which of the following is the most likely cause of the metabolic acidosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Methanol poisoning

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis: Typically presents with hyperglycemia >250 mg/dL and does not cause an elevated osmolal gap.
  • • Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis:
  • • Option C. Lactic acidosis: Would present with elevated lactate levels, and would not present with elevated osmolal gap.
  • • Option C. Lactic acidosis:
  • • Option D. Renal failure: Causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to retention of uremic toxins but does not cause an elevated osmolal gap.
  • • Option D. Renal failure:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of high anion gap metabolic acidosis with an elevated osmolal gap, toxic alcohol ingestion (e.g., methanol or ethylene glycol) should be strongly suspected. Calculate both gaps to narrow the differential diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with perioral tingling and paresthesias. His blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. His lab results are as follows: Sodium: 142 mEq/L Chloride: 110 mEq/L Bicarbonate: 32 mEq/L Urinary chloride: 10 mEq/L What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vomiting

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Bartter syndrome: Presents with metabolic alkalosis but is associated with high urinary chloride levels (> 20 mEq/L) due to renal chloride wasting. Blood pressure is usually normal or low.
  • • Option A. Bartter syndrome:
  • • Option B. Gitelman syndrome: Also causes metabolic alkalosis with high urinary chloride levels (> 20 mEq/L). It typically includes hypomagnesemia and hypocalciuria, which are not described here.
  • • Option B. Gitelman syndrome:
  • • Option D. Primary aldosteronism: Causes metabolic alkalosis with high urinary chloride levels (> 20 mEq/L) and is associated with hypertension due to mineralocorticoid excess, which is inconsistent with this patient’s low blood pressure.
  • • Option D. Primary aldosteronism:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metabolic alkalosis with low urinary chloride (< 20 mEq/L) is a hallmark of chloride-responsive alkalosis , commonly caused by vomiting or diuretic use. Alkalosis-induced hypocalcemia can lead to symptoms like paresthesias and perioral tingling.
  • ➤ low urinary chloride (< 20 mEq/L)
  • ➤ chloride-responsive alkalosis
  • ➤ hypocalcemia

questions.text: A patient presents with severe weakness and a long-standing history of dry mouth and dry eyes. His lab results are as follows: Serum Sodium (S. Na): 140 mEq/L Serum Potassium (S. K): 1.8 mEq/L Serum Chloride (S. Cl): 115 mEq/L Serum Bicarbonate (S. HCO₃): 12 mEq/L Urinary Sodium (Urinary Na): 25 mEq/L Urinary Potassium (Urinary K): 10 mEq/L Urinary Chloride (Urinary Cl): 20 mEq/L What is the most likely cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Distal RTA

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Proximal RTA: Causes bicarbonate wasting and is associated with a negative UAG. Hypokalemia is usually milder.
  • • Option A. Proximal RTA:
  • • Option C. Addison Disease: Leads to hyperkalemia due to aldosterone deficiency, which is inconsistent with the severe hypokalemia in this case.
  • • Option C. Addison Disease:
  • • Option D. Enterocutaneous Fistula: Causes bicarbonate loss leading to metabolic acidosis but is associated with a negative UAG due to increased NH₄⁺ excretion.
  • • Option D. Enterocutaneous Fistula:
  • • negative UAG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A positive urinary anion gap in the context of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis indicates impaired renal ammonium excretion, a hallmark of distal RTA . This is a key differentiating feature from gastrointestinal bicarbonate losses, which present with a negative UAG. Recognizing these patterns helps narrow the differential diagnosis.
  • ➤ distal RTA

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents with worsening fever, cough, and dyspnea for the past 2 days. He was started on empirical azithromycin 3 days ago, but his condition has worsened. ABG and lab results are as follows: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acute exacerbation of COPD

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Chronic respiratory acidosis: Chronic respiratory acidosis is expected in stable COPD patients with compensated hypercapnia. However, the low pH in this patient indicates an acute decompensation.
  • • Option B. Chronic respiratory acidosis:
  • • Option C. Acute respiratory acidosis: Pure acute respiratory acidosis would not explain the elevated bicarbonate, which reflects chronic compensation in COPD.
  • • Option C. Acute respiratory acidosis:
  • • Option D. Pulmonary embolism: Pulmonary embolism typically causes respiratory alkalosis due to hyperventilation, with low pCO₂ levels, not the hypercapnia seen here.
  • • Option D. Pulmonary embolism:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with known COPD, a low pH with elevated pCO₂ and bicarbonate indicates acute respiratory acidosis superimposed on chronic compensation, suggesting acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD) . Prompt recognition and treatment of the underlying cause, such as infection, are critical.
  • ➤ acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD)

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman (30 weeks gestation) has been diagnosed with pneumonia. She is currently receiving high-flow oxygen with an FiO₂ of 0.5. Her ABG and lab results are as follows: pH: 7.42 pCO₂: 29 mmHg HCO₃⁻: 20 mmol/L Base Excess: -5.1 mmol/L pO₂: 123 mmHg O₂ Saturation: 99% Potassium: 3.0 mmol/L Sodium: 133 mmol/L Chloride: 109 mmol/L What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type 1 respiratory failure

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): While ARDS can cause Type 1 respiratory failure, it typically presents with severe hypoxemia and bilateral infiltrates, and patients would not respond to 100% O2 due to significant shunting.
  • • Option A.
  • • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS):
  • • Option C. Alveolar hypoventilation: This condition leads to hypercapnia (elevated pCO₂), which is not present in this patient.
  • • Option C.
  • • Alveolar hypoventilation:
  • • Option D. Type 4 respiratory failure: Type 4 failure refers to hypoperfusion due to circulatory failure (e.g., septic shock), which is not indicated by the patient's ABG or clinical scenario.
  • • Option D.
  • • Type 4 respiratory failure:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type 1 respiratory failure is characterized by hypoxemia with a normal or low pCO₂ and is caused by V/Q mismatch, diffusion limitation, or shunting. An elevated A-a gradient with a good response to supplemental oxygen suggests V/Q mismatch, commonly seen in pneumonia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of alcohol use disorder presents with confusion and abdominal pain. His lab results are as follows: Sodium: 138 mEq/L Chloride: 102 mEq/L Bicarbonate: 12 mEq/L Blood glucose: 100 mg/dL Lactate: 3 mmol/L Serum osmolality: 350 mOsm/kg Ethanol level: Undetectable Urinary oxalate crystals: Present What is the most likely cause of his high anion gap metabolic acidosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ethylene glycol poisoning

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Methanol poisoning: Methanol poisoning causes high anion gap metabolic acidosis but typically presents with visual symptoms due to formate toxicity.
  • • Option A.
  • • Methanol poisoning:
  • • Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA): DKA causes high anion gap metabolic acidosis with elevated glucose, which is not present here.
  • • Option B.
  • • Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA):
  • • Option D. Lactic acidosis: Lactate is mildly elevated but not high enough to explain the metabolic acidosis.
  • • Option D.
  • • Lactic acidosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Suspect ethylene glycol poisoning in high anion gap metabolic acidosis with urinary oxalate crystals and an elevated osmolality gap.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). His ABG results show the following: pH: 7.37 pCO₂: 55 mmHg HCO₃⁻: 32 mEq/L Using the marked image, identify the most likely area (A-G) on the ABG nomogram corresponding to his clinical picture.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. A corresponds to a normal ABG, which does not match the patient's elevated pCO₂ and HCO₃⁻ values.
  • • Option A. A
  • • Option C. F represents acute metabolic acidosis, where pH would be significantly lower without compensatory bicarbonate elevation.
  • • Option C. F
  • • Option D. G represents metabolic acidosis with hyperchloremia or renal tubular acidosis, which does not fit this patient's findings.
  • • Option D. G

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the interpretation of ABG values in relation to the ABG nomogram and their clinical significance in chronic respiratory acidosis.

questions.text: Using the marked ABG nomogram, identify the area D.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acute respiratory alkalosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Metabolic alkalosis : Is associated with increased bicarbonate levels and compensatory respiratory changes, which do aligns with the region C on the given image.
  • • Option B. Metabolic alkalosis
  • • Option C. Chronic respiratory alkalosis : Would align with the region E on the given image.
  • • Option C. Chronic respiratory alkalosis
  • • Option D. Normal ABG: Values would fall within the central region (marked as A), not D.
  • • Option D. Normal ABG:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Use the ABG nomogram to identify and interpret patterns of acid-base disturbances, specifically differentiating acute from chronic respiratory and metabolic conditions.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with long-standing type 2 diabetes presents with fatigue, pruritus, and elevated creatinine. Renal ultrasound shows bilaterally small kidneys measuring 7 cm in length. Which of the following laboratory findings would best support a diagnosis of CKD rather than acute kidney injury (AKI)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Elevated serum creatinine kinase (CK) : Elevated CK is primarily seen in muscle damage, not CKD.
  • • Option A. Elevated serum creatinine kinase (CK)
  • • Option B. Hypercalcemia : CKD often leads to hypocalcemia (low calcium) due to impaired vitamin D metabolism, not hypercalcemia.
  • • Option B. Hypercalcemia
  • • Option D. Hypokalemia : Hypokalemia is not a primary feature of CKD, although it can occur in later stages due to medication use or other factors.
  • • Option D. Hypokalemia
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • CKD is characterized by a gradual decline in kidney function over months or years, while AKI is a sudden onset of kidney dysfunction. Elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) is a key laboratory marker for CKD due to secondary hyperparathyroidism caused by impaired vitamin D metabolism and phosphate retention.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical presentations would further support a diagnosis of chronic kidney disease (CKD) rather than acute kidney injury (AKI)?

options.label: A
options.text: Sudden onset of flank pain and hematuria

options.label: B
options.text: History of recent contrast dye exposure

options.label: D
options.text: Progressive worsening of anemia over several months

questions.correct_answer: D. Progressive worsening of anemia over several months
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Progressive worsening of anemia over several months

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Sudden onset of flank pain and hematuria : This presentation is more suggestive of an acute process, such as kidney stones or a urinary tract infection.
  • • Option A. Sudden onset of flank pain and hematuria
  • • Option B. History of recent contrast dye exposure : Contrast-induced nephropathy is an acute kidney injury that typically occurs within a few days of exposure to contrast dye.
  • • Option B. History of recent contrast dye exposure
  • • Option C. Hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis : While these electrolyte imbalances can occur in both AKI and CKD, they are more commonly associated with acute renal failure due to the rapid decline in kidney function.
  • • Option C. Hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • CKD typically presents with a gradual onset of symptoms such as fatigue, edema, and foamy urine, along with progressive anemia due to reduced erythropoietin production. In contrast, AKI presents with a sudden onset of symptoms like flank pain, hematuria, or recent exposure to nephrotoxic agents.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with acute onset oliguria and elevated creatinine. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and he reports recent episodes of diarrhea and vomiting. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his AKI?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prerenal azotemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN): While possible, it's less likely in this scenario without a history of nephrotoxic drug exposure or prolonged hypotension
  • • Option A.
  • • Acute tubular necrosis (ATN):
  • • Option C. Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN): This would typically present with fever, rash, or other signs of allergic reaction.
  • • Option C.
  • • Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN):
  • • Option D. Postrenal obstruction: Less likely given the absence of urinary symptoms suggestive of obstruction
  • • Option D.
  • • Postrenal obstruction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the different causes of acute kidney injury (AKI) and to be able to identify prerenal azotemia as the most likely cause in a patient with hypotension, dehydration, and oliguria. Prerenal azotemia is a functional AKI caused by decreased blood flow to the kidneys, often due to volume depletion or low blood pressure.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of heart failure and diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital with worsening shortness of breath and leg edema. His serum creatinine has increased from 1.2 mg/dL to 2.5 mg/dL over the past 2 days. Which of the following medications is most likely to have precipitated this acute kidney injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lisinopril

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Metformin : Metformin is not directly nephrotoxic but can cause lactic acidosis, which can worsen AKI.
  • • Option A. Metformin
  • • Option B. Furosemide : Furosemide, a diuretic, might worsen AKI if dehydration is the underlying cause.
  • • Option B.
  • • Furosemide
  • • Option D. Aspirin : Aspirin is not typically associated with AKI unless taken in very high doses.
  • • Option D. Aspirin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize that angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, such as lisinopril, can precipitate acute kidney injury (AKI) in patients with pre-existing cardiac or renal dysfunction. ACE inhibitors can decrease glomerular filtration rate (GFR) by reducing efferent arteriolar resistance, particularly in patients with decreased renal perfusion.

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios would classify a patient as having Stage 3 AKI?

options.label: A
options.text: A 40-year-old with baseline creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL, current creatinine of 2.6 mg/dL, and urine output of 0.4 mL/kg/hour for 18 hours.

options.label: B
options.text: A 25-year-old with a baseline creatinine of 0.9 mg/dL, current creatinine of 1.8 mg/dL, and anuria for 14 hours.

options.label: C
options.text: A 50-year-old with a baseline creatinine of 0.9 mg/dL, current creatinine of 1.5 mg/dL, and anuria for 10 hours.

options.label: D
options.text: A 15-year-old with a decrease in eGFR to 30 mL/min/1.73 m².

questions.correct_answer: D. A 15-year-old with a decrease in eGFR to 30 mL/min/1.73 m².
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) A 15-year-old with a decrease in eGFR to 30 mL/min/1.73 m².

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with nausea, vomiting, and oliguria. Her serum creatinine is 2.5 mg/dL, and her urine microscopy shows muddy brown granular casts. Which of the following biomarkers would be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis of acute tubular necrosis (ATN)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Urinary KIM-1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Plasma NGAL : While NGAL is an early marker for AKI, it's not specific for ATN and can be elevated in other causes of kidney injury.
  • • Option A. Plasma NGAL
  • • Option C. Plasma suPAR : suPAR is more useful in predicting the risk of developing AKI, not confirming ATN.
  • • Option C. Plasma suPAR
  • • Option D. Urinary TIMP-2 and IGFBP7 : These biomarkers are primarily used to predict the risk of severe AKI, not to diagnose the specific cause like ATN
  • • Option D. Urinary TIMP-2 and IGFBP7

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the role of urinary biomarkers, specifically KIM-1, in confirming the diagnosis of acute tubular necrosis (ATN). ATN is a common cause of acute kidney injury (AKI), characterized by damage to the renal tubules. Urinary KIM-1 is a highly sensitive and specific biomarker for ATN, as it is released from injured proximal tubular cells.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections presents with fever, chills, flank pain, and anuria. Ultrasound reveals bilateral hydronephrosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Percutaneous nephrostomy tube placement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Antibiotics alone : Antibiotics alone will not address the underlying obstruction causing the anuria and potential kidney damage.
  • • Option A. Antibiotics alone
  • • Option B. Intravenous fluids and observation : Intravenous fluids may worsen hydronephrosis and observation is not appropriate in the setting of anuria.
  • • Option B. Intravenous fluids and observation
  • • Option D. Ureteral stent placement : Ureteral stent placement, while a possible treatment, is not as immediate or effective as nephrostomy in relieving anuria
  • • Option D. Ureteral stent placement
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Obstructive uropathy can quickly lead to irreversible kidney damage, and immediate intervention with a percutaneous nephrostomy tube is often necessary to preserve renal function.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with no prior kidney disease undergoes elective abdominal aortic aneurysm repair requiring cross-clamping of the aorta above the renal arteries. The procedure lasts 45 minutes, and the patient's blood pressure is well-maintained throughout. Which of the following statements regarding the patient's risk of acute kidney injury (AKI) is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient is at high risk of developing severe AKI requiring dialysis.

options.label: B
options.text: The patient is at moderate risk of AKI, and close monitoring of renal function is necessary.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient is at low risk of severe AKI, as transient ischemia in a normal kidney is unlikely to cause significant damage.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient's risk of AKI cannot be determined without knowing their baseline creatinine level.

questions.correct_answer: C. The patient is at low risk of severe AKI, as transient ischemia in a normal kidney is unlikely to cause significant damage.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The patient is at low risk of severe AKI, as transient ischemia in a normal kidney is unlikely to cause significant damage.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. The patient is at high risk of developing severe AKI requiring dialysis : Severe AKI requiring dialysis is unlikely after a brief, well-managed ischemic event in a healthy individual.
  • • Option A. The patient is at high risk of developing severe AKI requiring dialysis
  • • Option B. The patient is at moderate risk of AKI, and close monitoring of renal function is necessary : While some degree of AKI is possible, it is unlikely to be moderate in this specific scenario with a normal kidney and controlled blood pressure.
  • • Option B. The patient is at moderate risk of AKI, and close monitoring of renal function is necessary
  • • Option D. The patient's risk of AKI cannot be determined without knowing their baseline creatinine level : While baseline creatinine is helpful, the focus here is the effect of transient ischemia on a normal kidney, not the pre-existing renal function.
  • • Option D. The patient's risk of AKI cannot be determined without knowing their baseline creatinine level
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Factors like adequate blood supply, autoregulation mechanisms, and cellular repair processes contribute to the kidney's resilience to transient ischemic events.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure (CHF) on furosemide presents with worsening dyspnea, oliguria, hypotension, and elevated serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels. Urinalysis demonstrates dilute urine. The treating physician is suspecting Pre-renal AKI rather than a ATN, which of the following findings supports his diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) FeNa < 1%

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. FeNa 1-2%: This is an indeterminate FeNa range, not definitively diagnostic of either prerenal AKI or ATN.
  • • Option B. FeNa 1-2%:
  • • Option C. FeNa 2-3%: This value suggests intrinsic renal injury, more characteristic of ATN where the tubules are unable to effectively reabsorb sodium.
  • • Option C. FeNa 2-3%:
  • • Option D. FeNa > 3%: A FeNa greater than 3% strongly suggests intrinsic renal injury, likely ATN, where the tubules have lost their reabsorptive capacity.
  • • Option D. FeNa > 3%:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • A low FeNa (<1%) is a hallmark of prerenal AKI, reflecting the kidney's attempt to conserve sodium in response to decreased renal perfusion.

questions.text: Which of the following medications has been shown to potentially prevent AKI in patients with cirrhosis and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis treated with antibiotics?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Albumin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Terlipressin : Terlipressin works by constricting blood vessels in the splanchnic circulation, which can improve blood flow to the kidneys.
  • • Option A. Terlipressin
  • • Option B. Octreotide : Octreotide reduces splanchnic blood flow and inhibits the release of hormones that worsen kidney function.
  • • Option B. Octreotide
  • • Option D. Midodrine : Midodrine is a vasopressor that helps to increase blood pressure and improve renal perfusion.
  • • Option D. Midodrine
  • • While these medications may indirectly improve kidney function in some patients, they are not the first-line therapy for preventing AKI in SBP. Albumin administration, on the other hand, has been shown to be more effective in this specific context.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand that albumin administration is an effective intervention for preventing acute kidney injury (AKI) in patients with cirrhosis and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) treated with antibiotics. Albumin helps improve renal perfusion and reduce inflammation, thereby mitigating the risk of AKI in this specific population.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient with decompensated cirrhosis and refractory ascites presents with oliguria, worsening creatinine, and a low urine sodium concentration (<10 mEq/L). Despite aggressive volume resuscitation with albumin, their renal function continues to decline. Which of the following represents the definitive treatment for their underlying condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Liver transplantation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Terlipressin and albumin: These are vasoconstrictor medications used as a bridge to transplant in HRS, providing temporary improvement in renal function.
  • • Option A. Terlipressin and albumin:
  • • Option B. Octreotide and midodrine: This combination is another pharmacologic therapy used to manage HRS, but it doesn't address the root cause.
  • • Option B. Octreotide and midodrine:
  • • Option C. Continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT): While CRRT can provide temporary support for kidney function, it does not treat the underlying cause of HRS and is not a definitive treatment.
  • • Option C. Continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize that liver transplantation is the definitive treatment for hepatorenal syndrome (HRS), a serious complication of advanced cirrhosis characterized by renal failure. While pharmacological interventions like terlipressin, albumin, octreotide, and midodrine can provide temporary support, they do not address the underlying liver dysfunction that drives HRS.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a proposed mechanism for the cardiorenal syndrome in ADHF?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced renal perfusion due to low cardiac output

options.label: B
options.text: Increased venous congestion leading to renal venous hypertension

options.label: D
options.text: Direct nephrotoxicity of heart failure medications.

questions.correct_answer: A. Reduced renal perfusion due to low cardiac output
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reduced renal perfusion due to low cardiac output.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Increased venous congestion leading to renal venous hypertension: In ADHF, the heart's reduced pumping capacity can lead to a backup of blood in the veins, including those draining the kidneys. This increased pressure can impede blood flow through the kidneys, leading to decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and contributing to CRS.
  • • Option B. Increased venous congestion leading to renal venous hypertension:
  • • Option C. Neurohormonal activation (RAAS, SNS): In response to decreased cardiac output, the body activates neurohormonal systems like the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) and the sympathetic nervous system (SNS). These systems can cause vasoconstriction in the kidneys, further reducing blood flow and contributing to renal dysfunction.
  • • Option C. Neurohormonal activation (RAAS, SNS):
  • • Option D. Direct nephrotoxicity of heart failure medications: Some medications used to treat heart failure, such as certain diuretics and NSAIDs, can be directly toxic to the kidneys, especially in patients with pre-existing renal dysfunction. This can worsen or precipitate AKI in the context of CRS.
  • • Option D. Direct nephrotoxicity of heart failure medications:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the pathophysiology of cardiorenal syndrome (CRS) in acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF), recognizing that reduced renal perfusion due to low cardiac output is NOT a primary mechanism in most cases. Instead, venous congestion, neurohormonal activation, and direct nephrotoxicity of medications are the main contributors to this complex syndrome.

questions.text: A patient with stage 4 CKD on dialysis develops nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) after an MRI. Which contrast agent was most likely used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gadolinium-based contrast agent (GBCA)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Iodine- based contrast agents: These are primarily used in X-ray and CT imaging. While they can cause contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN), they are not associated with nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF).
  • • Option B. Iodine-
  • • based contrast agents:
  • • Option C. Barium sulfate: This contrast agent is used for gastrointestinal imaging and is not typically administered intravenously. Thus, it would not be expected to cause NSF, which is related to systemic exposure to contrast agents.
  • • Option C. Barium
  • • sulfate:
  • • Option D. Air contrast : This is not a chemical contrast agent, but rather air or carbon dioxide used to enhance the visibility of certain structures in imaging studies. It does not pose a risk of NSF
  • • Option D. Air contrast
  • • :

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the association between gadolinium-based contrast agents (GBCAs) and nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) in patients with advanced kidney disease. Recognizing that GBCA exposure is the primary risk factor for NSF is crucial for preventing this debilitating condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic patient with chronic kidney disease (eGFR 35 mL/min) is scheduled for a coronary angiogram. Which of the following measures is most likely to prevent contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN)?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer high-dose furosemide before and after the procedure.

options.label: B
options.text: Use low-osmolar or iso-osmolar contrast media.

options.label: D
options.text: Hold metformin for 48 hours before and after the procedure.

questions.correct_answer: B. Use low-osmolar or iso-osmolar contrast media.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Use low-osmolar or iso-osmolar contrast media.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Administer high-dose furosemide before and after the procedure : Furosemide may actually worsen renal function in this setting.
  • • Option A. Administer high-dose furosemide before and after the procedure
  • • Option C. Pretreat with oral N-acetylcysteine : N-acetylcysteine has limited evidence for CIN prevention.
  • • Option C. Pretreat with oral N-acetylcysteine
  • • Option D. Hold metformin for 48 hours before and after the procedure : Metformin is held due to lactic acidosis risk, not CIN.
  • • Option D. Hold metformin for 48 hours before and after the procedure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the importance of using low-osmolar or iso-osmolar contrast media in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) to prevent contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN). While other measures like hydration and withholding certain medications are also important, the choice of contrast agent plays a significant role in mitigating the risk of CIN in these patients.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with livedo reticularis, blue toes, and acute kidney injury (AKI) after undergoing a coronary angiogram. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Atheroembolic renal disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis : AIN is not associated with livedo reticularis or blue toes.
  • • Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis
  • • Option B. Contrast-induced nephropathy : CIN typically presents within 24-48 hours of contrast exposure, not days later.
  • • Option B. Contrast-induced nephropathy
  • • Option D. Cholesterol emboli syndrome : While similar, cholesterol emboli syndrome typically lacks renal involvement
  • • Option D. Cholesterol emboli syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the classic presentation of atheroembolic renal disease (AERD), which includes livedo reticularis, blue toes (cyanosis), and acute kidney injury (AKI) following a vascular procedure. This triad of symptoms is highly suggestive of AERD and should prompt further investigation and appropriate management.

questions.text: A patient with rhabdomyolysis develops acute kidney injury (AKI). Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of AKI in this setting?

options.label: C
options.text: Renal tubular obstruction by myoglobin casts

questions.correct_answer: C. Renal tubular obstruction by myoglobin casts
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Renal tubular obstruction by myoglobin casts

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Immune-mediated glomerulonephritis: This is an inflammatory process affecting the glomeruli (filtering units of the kidney) and is not the primary mechanism in rhabdomyolysis-induced AKI.
  • • Option A. Immune-mediated glomerulonephritis:
  • • Option B. Renal artery stenosis: This is a narrowing of the artery supplying the kidney, which can reduce blood flow and cause kidney damage, but it is not directly related to rhabdomyolysis.
  • • Option B. Renal artery stenosis:
  • • Option D. Crystal nephropathy: This is caused by the deposition of crystals in the kidneys, most commonly from medications like acyclovir or sulfa drugs, and is not the primary mechanism in rhabdomyolysis.
  • • Option D. Crystal nephropathy:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • The pathophysiology of acute kidney injury (AKI) in rhabdomyolysis, specifically recognizing that renal tubular obstruction by myoglobin casts is the primary mechanism.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is known to increase the risk of rhabdomyolysis?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) All of the above

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with acute kidney injury (AKI), fever, maculopapular rash, and arthralgias after recently starting a new medication. A renal biopsy is performed. Which of the following HPE findings will be seen in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Glomerular crescent formation and fibrinoid necrosis

options.label: C
options.text: Interstitial edema and inflammatory infiltrate with predominantly eosinophils

options.label: D
options.text: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with immune complex deposits

questions.correct_answer: C. Interstitial edema and inflammatory infiltrate with predominantly eosinophils
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Interstitial edema and inflammatory infiltrate with predominantly eosinophils

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Glomerular crescent formation and fibrinoid necrosis: These are characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), a different type of kidney disease.
  • • Option A. Glomerular crescent formation and fibrinoid necrosis:
  • • Option B. Tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis: These findings are more indicative of chronic kidney disease (CKD) rather than the acute inflammatory process of AIN.
  • • Option B. Tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis:
  • • Option D. Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with immune complex deposits: This is a common feature of immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis, not AIN.
  • • Option D. Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with immune complex deposits:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • The characteristic histopathological features of acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) on a renal biopsy, which include interstitial edema, inflammatory infiltrate with predominantly eosinophils, and tubulitis. Recognizing these findings is crucial for the accurate diagnosis and management of AIN, a common cause of acute kidney injury (AKI).

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with fever, flank pain, and dysuria. Urinalysis is performed as part of her evaluation, which is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pyelonephritis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Acute glomerulonephritis : Acute glomerulonephritis is usually characterized by hypertension, hematuria with red blood cell casts, proteinuria, and varying degrees of renal insufficiency, which is not consistent with the presented findings.
  • • Option
  • • A. Acute glomerulonephritis
  • • Option C. Acute interstitial nephritis : Acute interstitial nephritis typically presents with a rash, fever, and eosinophilia and is often a hypersensitivity reaction to medications. WBC casts may be present, but the clinical symptoms and the absence of medication history make this less likely.
  • • Option
  • • C. Acute interstitial nephritis
  • • Option D. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) : Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) often presents with a history of ischemia or nephrotoxic injury, and the urinalysis would typically show muddy brown casts, not the white blood cell casts indicative of infection.
  • • Option
  • • D. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Pyelonephritis is diagnosed based on the combination of clinical symptoms such as fever, flank pain, and dysuria, along with laboratory findings of white blood cell casts in the urine, indicating an infection that has reached the renal pelvis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with oliguria, weakness, nausea, and recent initiation of a new anti-hypertensive medication. He has elevated creatinine, BUN, and hyperkalemia. Urinalysis slide is shown below. What’s the most likely cause of his kidney injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute tubular necrosis (ATN)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Prerenal azotemia: While possible given the patient's history, prerenal AKI usually presents with bland urine sediment and a BUN/creatinine ratio >20:1. The presence of granular casts makes this diagnosis less likely.
  • • Option A. Prerenal azotemia:
  • • Option C. Acute glomerulonephritis: This typically presents with hematuria, proteinuria, and RBC casts. The absence of these findings and the presence of granular casts make this diagnosis less likely.
  • • Option C. Acute glomerulonephritis:
  • • Option D. Postrenal obstruction: This would likely present with anuria and pain. Ultrasound would be needed to confirm this diagnosis. The presence of granular casts points toward intrinsic renal injury rather than obstruction.
  • • Option D. Postrenal obstruction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The characteristic findings of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) on urinalysis, which include muddy brown granular casts. These casts, in combination with the patient's clinical presentation and history (recent medication change, elevated creatinine, BUN, and hyperkalemia), can help distinguish ATN from other causes of acute kidney injury (AKI).

questions.text: Which dialysis modality is most appropriate for a hemodynamically unstable patient with AKI and severe fluid overload?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Intermittent hemodialysis : Intermittent hemodialysis can cause hemodynamic instability in these patients.
  • • Option
  • • A. Intermittent hemodialysis
  • • Option C. Peritoneal dialysis : Peritoneal dialysis is less efficient and may not be suitable for severe fluid overload.
  • • Option
  • • C. Peritoneal dialysis
  • • Option D. Sustained low-efficiency dialysis (SLED) : SLED is a hybrid modality but may not be tolerated in unstable patients
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Sustained low-efficiency dialysis (SLED)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the role of continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) as the preferred dialysis modality for hemodynamically unstable patients with acute kidney injury (AKI) and severe fluid overload. CRRT allows for gentle and continuous removal of fluids and solutes, minimizing the risk of hypotension compared to intermittent hemodialysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an absolute indication for dialysis in AKI?

options.label: A
options.text: Severe hyperkalemia unresponsive to medical therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Severe fluid overload unresponsive to diuretics

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) BUN level of 120 mg/Dl

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Severe hyperkalemia unresponsive to medical therapy , Option B. Uremic pericarditis and Option C. Severe fluid overload unresponsive to diuretics : These are all absolute indications for dialysis in AKI.
  • • Option A. Severe hyperkalemia unresponsive to medical therapy
  • • Option
  • • B. Uremic pericarditis
  • • Option C. Severe fluid overload unresponsive to diuretics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The absolute indications for dialysis in AKI, which include severe hyperkalemia unresponsive to medical therapy, uremic pericarditis, and severe fluid overload unresponsive to diuretics. Elevated BUN alone is not an absolute indication, and the decision to initiate dialysis should be based on the overall clinical context and the presence of life-threatening complications.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: It measures BP every 15-30 minutes during the day and every 15-60 minutes at night.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides a more comprehensive assessment of BP than isolated clinic readings.

options.label: C
options.text: It is less reliable than home BP monitoring for predicting target organ damage.

options.label: D
options.text: An attenuated nocturnal BP dip is associated with increased cardiovascular risk.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is less reliable than home BP monitoring for predicting target organ damage.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is less reliable than home BP monitoring for predicting target organ damage.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. It measures BP every 15-30 minutes during the day and every 15-60 minutes at night : ABPM takes frequent BP readings throughout the day and night, providing a more complete picture than clinic readings.
  • • Option A. It measures BP every 15-30 minutes during the day and every 15-60 minutes at night
  • • Option B. It provides a more comprehensive assessment of BP than isolated clinic readings : ABPM captures BP variations throughout the day, unlike isolated clinic readings.
  • • Option B. It provides a more comprehensive assessment of BP than isolated clinic readings
  • • Option D. An attenuated nocturnal BP dip is associated with increased cardiovascular risk : Less pronounced or absent nocturnal BP dips are linked to higher cardiovascular risk. ABPM helps identify these patterns.
  • • Option D. An attenuated nocturnal BP dip is associated with increased cardiovascular risk
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • ABPM is a valuable tool for diagnosing and managing hypertension because it provides a more complete and accurate assessment of blood pressure patterns than other methods.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman visits her primary care physician for an annual health examination. Her blood pressure is measured as 135/85 mmHg, with no prior history of hypertension. The physician schedules two additional blood pressure measurements over the next month. Which of the following methods is the physician using to diagnose hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) OBPM (Office Blood Pressure Monitoring)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation

While ABPM and HBPM are valuable tools for monitoring blood pressure and assessing its patterns, they are not typically the first step in diagnosing hypertension.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with a family history of hypertension has normal clinic blood pressure readings (128/82 mmHg) but 24-hour ambulatory monitoring reveals consistently elevated readings (135-145/85-90 mmHg). What is the most likely diagnosis?

Ans. B) Masked hypertension

  • • Option A. White coat hypertension
  • • Option C. Primary hypertension : While this patient likely has hypertension, the term "primary" doesn't account for the specific pattern seen here with normal clinic readings.
  • • Option C. Primary hypertension
  • • Option D. Secondary hypertension : This refers to hypertension caused by an underlying medical condition, which is not indicated in this scenario.
  • • Option D. Secondary hypertension
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • The diagnosis in this case is masked hypertension , characterized by normal blood pressure readings in a clinical setting but elevated readings during ambulatory monitoring. This highlights the importance of using ambulatory monitoring to accurately assess blood pressure and diagnose hypertension, especially in individuals with a family history of hypertension or other risk factors.
  • • masked hypertension

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with well-controlled type 2 diabetes presents for a routine health examination. Her in-office blood pressure is 142/88 mmHg, but her average blood pressure at home over two weeks is 122/78 mmHg. She reports feeling nervous during medical appointments. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) White coat hypertension

  • • :

  • • Option A. Masked hypertension:
  • • Option C. Primary hypertension: While this patient may eventually develop sustained hypertension, the current findings are not consistent with this diagnosis. Primary hypertension would typically present with consistently elevated readings in both clinic and home settings.
  • • Option C. Primary hypertension:
  • • Option D. Secondary hypertension: This refers to hypertension caused by an underlying medical condition, such as renal artery stenosis or pheochromocytoma. There is no indication of secondary hypertension in this patient's history or presentation.
  • • Option D. Secondary hypertension:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • The diagnosis in this case is white coat hypertension , where blood pressure readings are elevated in a clinical setting but normal at home. This is often caused by anxiety or stress related to the medical environment, which the patient reports experiencing.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a pheochromocytoma scheduled for surgical resection presents with a blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg and episodic headaches and sweating. Which of the following medications should be initiated pre-operatively?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alpha-blocker (e.g., phenoxybenzamine)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Beta-blocker: Beta-blockers should be avoided initially as they can worsen hypertension by causing unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation. They may be added later for tachycardia control after adequate alpha-blockade is established.
  • • Option A. Beta-blocker:
  • • Option C. Calcium channel blocker: While calcium channel blockers have antihypertensive effects, they are not the first-line agents for pheochromocytoma and are less effective in controlling the episodic hypertension caused by catecholamine surges.
  • • Option C. Calcium channel blocker:
  • • Option D. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor): ACE inhibitors are not recommended for initial blood pressure control in pheochromocytoma, as they do not directly address the underlying catecholamine excess and may not effectively control blood pressure fluctuations.
  • • Option D. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor):
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Alpha-blockers are the first-line medication for pre-operative blood pressure control in patients with pheochromocytoma. They counteract the effects of catecholamines released by the tumor, preventing hypertensive crises during surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital cardiovascular conditions is most commonly associated with hypertension in children and young adults?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Coarctation of the aorta

  • • Option B. Atrial septal defect (ASD):
  • • Option D. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSD is a hole in the wall separating the ventricles. It can cause heart failure if large, but doesn't typically cause isolated hypertension.
  • • Option D. Ventricular septal defect (VSD):

  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Coarctation of the aorta is the most common congenital heart defect associated with hypertension in children and young adults. This narrowing of the aorta increases blood pressure before the constriction and can lead to various symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about alcohol consumption and blood pressure is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Moderate alcohol consumption has no effect on blood pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: Drinking three or more alcoholic drinks per day is associated with lower blood pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Reducing alcohol consumption can lead to a decrease in blood pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: Alcohol consumption has no impact on the risk of stroke.

questions.correct_answer: C. Reducing alcohol consumption can lead to a decrease in blood pressure.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reducing alcohol consumption can lead to a decrease in blood pressure.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Moderate alcohol consumption has no effect on blood pressure : Moderate alcohol consumption may have a slight effect on blood pressure, but it is not considered neutral.
  • • Option A. Moderate alcohol consumption has no effect on blood pressure
  • • Option B. Drinking three or more alcoholic drinks per day is associated with lower blood pressure : Excessive alcohol intake is associated with higher , not lower, blood pressure.
  • • Option B.
  • • Drinking three or more alcoholic drinks per day is associated with lower blood pressure
  • • Option D. Alcohol consumption has no impact on the risk of stroke : Excessive alcohol intake is a risk factor for stroke.
  • • Option D. Alcohol consumption has no impact on the risk of stroke
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Excessive alcohol consumption is a modifiable risk factor for hypertension. Reducing alcohol intake can lead to a decrease in blood pressure, improving overall cardiovascular health and reducing the risk of stroke.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with hypertension presents with a blood pressure of 210/120 mmHg, headache, and mild dyspnea. He has no evidence of acute organ damage. What is the best management strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate BP reduction to normal with IV drugs.

options.label: B
options.text: Gradual BP reduction to 25% of initial value over 24 hours.

options.label: C
options.text: ICU admission for aggressive BP control.

questions.correct_answer: B. Gradual BP reduction to 25% of initial value over 24 hours.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gradual BP reduction to 25% of initial value over 24 hours.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Immediate BP reduction to normal with IV drugs : Immediate reduction to normal BP is too aggressive for a hypertensive urgency and could cause ischemia.
  • • Option A.
  • • Immediate BP reduction to normal with IV drugs
  • • Option C. ICU admission for aggressive BP control : ICU admission is unnecessary as there is no evidence of organ damage.
  • • Option C. ICU admission for aggressive BP control
  • • Option D. Discharge with outpatient follow-up : Discharge without treatment is inappropriate due to the severity of the hypertension.
  • • Option D. Discharge with outpatient follow-up
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • The distinction between hypertensive urgency and emergency is crucial for appropriate management. Hypertensive urgency requires gradual blood pressure reduction, while hypertensive emergency necessitates rapid intervention to prevent end-organ damage.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease presents with a blood pressure of 200/120 mmHg and acute visual disturbances. Which of the following is the most appropriate medication for initial blood pressure control in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Intravenous labetalol

  • • Option B. Oral clonidine : Oral clonidine is not used in hypertensive emergencies due to its slow onset of action.
  • • Option B. Oral clonidine
  • • Option D. Sublingual nifedipine : Sublingual nifedipine is associated with unpredictable blood pressure drops and is not recommended.
  • • Option D. Sublingual nifedipine
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Intravenous labetalol is a preferred medication for initial blood pressure control in hypertensive emergencies, especially in patients with underlying renal disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a cause of hypovolemic hyponatremia with a urine sodium level greater than 20 mEq/L?

options.label: D
options.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

questions.correct_answer: D. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Diuretic excess, Option B. Mineralocorticoid deficiency, and Option C. Cerebral salt wasting syndrome are all causes of hypovolemic hyponatremia with a urine sodium level greater than 20 mEq/L.
  • • Option A. Diuretic excess, Option B. Mineralocorticoid deficiency, and Option C. Cerebral salt wasting syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the different types of hyponatremia and their associated urine sodium levels. Hypovolemic hyponatremia with a urine sodium level greater than 20 mEq/L is caused by renal sodium loss (e.g., diuretics, mineralocorticoid deficiency) or extrarenal sodium loss (e.g., cerebral salt wasting). SIADH is euvolemic hyponatremia with high urine sodium due to excessive water retention.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with a history of congestive heart failure presents with confusion, nausea, and a serum sodium level of 128 mEq/L. Her physical exam reveals jugular venous distention and bilateral crackles on lung auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her hyponatremia?

options.label: A
options.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypervolemic hyponatremia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH): While SIADH can cause hyponatremia, it is typically euvolemic (normal fluid volume status) and does not present with signs of fluid overload like JVD and crackles.
  • • Option A. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH):
  • • Option B. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism can cause mild hyponatremia, but it is usually not associated with the degree of hyponatremia and fluid overload seen in this patient.
  • • Option B. Hypothyroidism:
  • • Option C. Primary adrenal insufficiency: Primary adrenal insufficiency can cause hyponatremia due to aldosterone deficiency. However, it typically presents with additional symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and hypotension, which are not present in this patient.
  • • Option C. Primary adrenal insufficiency:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the clinical presentation of hypervolemic hyponatremia, which is characterized by low serum sodium, fluid overload (JVD, edema, crackles), and often associated with underlying conditions like heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a common cause of euvolemic hyponatremia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cirrhosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone secretion): In SIADH, excess antidiuretic hormone (ADH) leads to water retention, diluting sodium levels. However, the body's total sodium content remains normal, resulting in euvolemic hyponatremia.
  • • Option A. SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone secretion):
  • • Option B. Primary polydipsia: Excessive water intake in individuals with normal kidney function can overwhelm the kidneys' ability to excrete water, leading to dilutional hyponatremia without changes in total body sodium (euvolemic).
  • • Option B. Primary polydipsia:
  • • Option C. Hypothyroidism: In hypothyroidism, decreased thyroid hormone levels can impair water excretion by the kidneys, leading to water retention and dilutional hyponatremia without changes in total body sodium (euvolemic).
  • • Option C. Hypothyroidism:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand that cirrhosis is typically associated with hypervolemic hyponatremia, not euvolemic hyponatremia. Euvolemic hyponatremia is usually caused by SIADH, primary polydipsia, or hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A patient with severe hyponatremia (serum sodium 115 mEq/L) develops seizures and altered mental status. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypertonic saline infusion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Fluid restriction : Fluid restriction is appropriate for mild hyponatremia.
  • • Option A. Fluid restriction
  • • Option B. Normal saline infusion : Normal saline is not effective in severe hyponatremia.
  • • Option B. Normal saline infusion
  • • Option D. Demeclocycline : Demeclocycline is used for chronic SIADH, not acute, severe hyponatremia.
  • • Option D. Demeclocycline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize severe symptomatic hyponatremia as a medical emergency requiring prompt treatment with hypertonic saline (3%) to rapidly raise serum sodium levels and prevent neurological complications.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is NOT associated with the development of SIAD?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation

  • • Option A. Chlorpropamide
  • • Option B. Carbamazepine
  • • Option D. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize that hydrochlorothiazide is not associated with the development of SIADH, while other medications like chlorpropamide, carbamazepine, and SSRIs can stimulate ADH release or enhance its action, leading to SIADH. Understanding the potential side effects of medications is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management of hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with small cell lung cancer presents with chronic hyponatremia (125 mEq/L) due to SIADH. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:

  • • Option A. Hypertonic saline (3%) infusion
  • • Option C. Demeclocycline : Demeclocycline is a second-line agent used if fluid restriction fails.
  • • Option C. Demeclocycline
  • • Option D. Tolvaptan : Tolvaptan is a vasopressin receptor antagonist, also considered second-line after fluid restriction.
  • • Option D.
  • • Tolvaptan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand that fluid restriction is the most appropriate initial treatment for chronic SIADH, as it allows for gradual correction of hyponatremia without the risks associated with more aggressive therapies like hypertonic saline or medications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a recent subarachnoid hemorrhage develops hyponatremia, hypotension, and polyuria. His urine sodium is 50 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
