  • • Option C. Primary polydipsia : Euvolemic with low urine sodium.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the characteristic features of cerebral salt wasting (CSW), a syndrome that can occur after brain injury and presents with hyponatremia, hypovolemia, and elevated urine sodium. Distinguishing CSW from other causes of hyponatremia, such as SIADH, is crucial for appropriate management.

questions.text: A patient with hypovolemic hyponatremia and a urine sodium of 10 mEq/L should be treated with:

Ans. C) Normal saline

  • • Option B. Hypertonic saline : Hypertonic saline is not the initial choice for hypovolemic hyponatremia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

  • • Option
  • • B. Oral urea
  • • Option D. Corticosteroids : Corticosteroids have no proven benefit in preventing ODS.
  • • Option D. Corticosteroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize that re-lowering of plasma sodium concentration with desmopressin (DDAVP) and/or free water is the most effective intervention for preventing or attenuating osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS) after overly rapid correction of hyponatremia. This is based on the principle of reversing the osmotic gradient that causes myelinolysis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with dementia presents with lethargy, decreased oral intake for two days, and a serum sodium of 160 mEq/L. His weight is 70kg. Assuming total body water (TBW) is 60% of his body weight, what is his estimated free water deficit?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6 liters

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. 2 liters, Option B. 4 liters and Option D. 8 liters: These options represent incorrect calculations of the free water deficit using the formula above.
  • • Option A. 2 liters, Option B. 4 liters
  • • Option D. 8 liters:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand how to calculate free water deficit in a patient with hypernatremia. This is a crucial step in determining the appropriate amount of fluid replacement needed to correct the hypernatremia safely.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical ECG finding in hyperkalemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) U waves

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Peaked T waves, Option B. Prolonged PR interval and Option D. Widened QRS complex : These are all characteristic ECG changes seen in hyperkalemia.
  • • Option A.
  • • Peaked T waves, Option B. Prolonged PR interval
  • • Option
  • • D. Widened QRS
  • • complex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the characteristic ECG findings in hyperkalemia, which include peaked T waves, prolonged PR interval, and widened QRS complex. U waves, on the other hand, are typically associated with hypokalemia. Understanding these ECG changes is crucial for the prompt diagnosis and management of hyperkalemia, a potentially life-threatening electrolyte imbalance.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with muscle weakness, peaked T waves on ECG, and a serum potassium level of 7.0 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate intervention?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Administer intravenous calcium gluconate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Administer oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate ( Kayexalate) : Kayexalate is a potassium binder but works too slowly for acute hyperkalemia.
  • • Option A. Administer oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate (
  • • Kayexalate)
  • • Option C. Initiate hemodialysis : Hemodialysis is effective but may not be immediately available.
  • • Option C. Initiate hemodialysis
  • • Option D. Administer intravenous insulin and glucose : Insulin and glucose shift potassium intracellularly, but calcium should be given first to protect the heart.
  • • Option D. Administer intravenous insulin and glucose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the importance of administering intravenous calcium gluconate as the immediate intervention for patients presenting with hyperkalemia and ECG changes. This medication acts quickly to stabilize the cardiac membrane and protect against potentially fatal arrhythmias. While other options like Kayexalate, hemodialysis, and insulin/glucose can help lower potassium levels, they may not act rapidly enough to prevent immediate cardiac complications.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of chronic diarrhea presents with muscle weakness, fatigue, and palpitations. Her serum potassium is 2.8 mEq/L. Which of the following ECG findings would be most consistent with her presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prominent U waves

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Peaked T waves : Peaked T waves are associated with hyperkalemia.
  • • Option A. Peaked T waves
  • • Option B. Shortened QT interval : Hypokalemia typically prolongs the QT interval, not shortens it.
  • • Option
  • • B. Shortened QT interval
  • • Option D. ST segment elevation : ST segment elevation is typically seen in myocardial infarction or pericarditis.
  • • Option D. ST segment elevation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the characteristic ECG finding of hypokalemia, which is the presence of prominent U waves. This finding, along with the patient's symptoms (muscle weakness, fatigue, palpitations) and history of chronic diarrhea (a potential cause of potassium loss), helps confirm the diagnosis of hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents with altered mental status, Kussmaul respirations, and fruity breath. Labs show glucose of 650 mg/dL, pH of 7.20, and potassium of 2.9 mEq/L. Which mechanism best explains his hypokalemia?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased urinary potassium excretion due to glycosuria

options.label: C
options.text: Insulin deficiency-induced intracellular shift of potassium

options.label: D
options.text: Shift of potassium into cells in exchange for hydrogen ions

questions.correct_answer: D. Shift of potassium into cells in exchange for hydrogen ions
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Shift of potassium into cells in exchange for hydrogen ions.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • DKA causes urinary potassium loss and a shift of potassium into cells to buffer acidosis. This initial exchange can lead to a temporary rise in potassium, but overall potassium stores are depleted.
  • • Explanation :
  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Increased urinary potassium excretion due to glycosuria: While glycosuria (glucose in the urine) can contribute to potassium loss, it is not the primary mechanism in DKA. The exchange mechanism with hydrogen ions plays a more significant role.
  • • Option A. Increased urinary potassium excretion due to glycosuria:
  • • Option B. Vomiting-induced potassium loss: Vomiting can cause hypokalemia, but it is not the dominant factor in DKA, where the underlying metabolic derangements are more critical.
  • • Option B. Vomiting-induced potassium loss:
  • • Option C. Insulin deficiency-induced intracellular shift of potassium: Insulin deficiency does initially cause potassium to shift out of cells, leading to a temporary increase in serum potassium. However, this is followed by the exchange with hydrogen ions, resulting in overall potassium depletion.
  • • Option C. Insulin deficiency-induced intracellular shift of potassium:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the complex mechanisms of hypokalemia in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). It is important to recognize that the initial hyperkalemia is transient, and the overall effect is total body potassium depletion due to the shift of potassium into cells to buffer acidosis and urinary potassium loss through glycosuria. This understanding is crucial for appropriate management of DKA, which includes potassium replacement along with insulin and fluid therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with muscle cramps and weakness. Her serum potassium is 2.5 mEq/L. She has been taking furosemide for hypertension and reports frequent watery diarrhea. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. What is the most likely cause of her hypokalemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diuretic use

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Gitelman syndrome: This is a genetic disorder causing hypokalemia, but it typically presents with milder hypokalemia and often involves low urine calcium excretion, which is not mentioned in the case.
  • • Option A. Gitelman syndrome:
  • • Option B. Primary hyperaldosteronism: This condition can cause hypokalemia due to increased potassium excretion, but it usually leads to high blood pressure, which is not present in this case.
  • • Option B. Primary hyperaldosteronism:
  • • Option C. Renal tubular acidosis (RTA): RTA can also cause hypokalemia, but it often presents with metabolic acidosis, which is not mentioned in the case.
  • • Option C. Renal tubular acidosis (RTA):
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • To identify diuretic use as the most common cause of hypokalemia in patients presenting with muscle cramps and weakness, especially in those with a history of diuretic therapy and additional sources of potassium loss like diarrhea.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of Crohn's disease and chronic diarrhea presents with fatigue and muscle cramps. Laboratory tests reveal a serum potassium of 3.0 mEq/L and metabolic alkalosis. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of her hypokalemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gastrointestinal losses

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Renal tubular acidosis : Renal tubular acidosis typically presents with metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia, not alkalosis and hypokalemia.
  • • Option A. Renal tubular acidosis
  • • Option B. Primary hyperaldosteronism : Primary hyperaldosteronism causes hypokalemia but not metabolic alkalosis.
  • • Option
  • • B. Primary hyperaldosteronism
  • • Option D. Diuretic use : Diuretic use is not mentioned in the patient's history
  • • Option D. Diuretic use

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the association between chronic diarrhea in Crohn's disease and hypokalemia with metabolic alkalosis. Gastrointestinal losses of potassium and bicarbonate can lead to this electrolyte imbalance.

questions.text: A 28-year-old athlete presents with sudden-onset muscle paralysis after completing a marathon. He has been consuming large amounts of water during the race. His blood pressure is normal, and he is afebrile. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypokalemic periodic paralysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Exertional rhabdomyolysis: While marathon running can cause rhabdomyolysis, this would usually present with muscle pain, weakness, and dark urine, rather than sudden paralysis.
  • • Option B. Exertional rhabdomyolysis:
  • • Option C. Heat stroke: Heat stroke would likely cause hyperthermia and altered mental status, neither of which is mentioned in this scenario.
  • • Option C. Heat stroke:
  • • Option D. Hyponatremia: Excessive water intake during a marathon can cause hyponatremia, which can also lead to neurological symptoms, but sudden paralysis is more characteristic of hypokalemic periodic paralysis.
  • • Option D. Hyponatremia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand that hypokalemic periodic paralysis can present with sudden-onset muscle paralysis, often triggered by strenuous exercise and excessive water intake. This condition should be considered in athletes experiencing such symptoms after intense physical activity.

questions.text: You are preparing to administer potassium chloride (KCl) to a patient with hypokalemia. The physician has ordered 40 mEq of KCl, and the available solution concentration is 2 mEq/mL. How many milliliters of KCl should you draw up in the syringe?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 20 mL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the calculation of medication dosage and volume based on the desired dose and concentration of the solution. In this case, the formula Volume (mL) = Dose (mEq) / Concentration (mEq/mL) was used to determine the correct volume of potassium chloride (KCl) to administer.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism and diuretic use is admitted to the hospital for community-acquired pneumonia. Laboratory results reveal a serum potassium level of 2.8 mEq/L and an ECG demonstrating flattened T waves and prominent U waves. What other electrolyte abnormality are you suspecting in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypomagnesemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Hypernatremia: Hypernatremia (high sodium) is not typically associated with hypokalemia in this clinical scenario. Alcoholism is more often associated with hyponatremia (low sodium).
  • • Option A. Hypernatremia:
  • • Option B. Hypocalcemia: While hypocalcemia can occur in alcoholics, it is not directly related to hypokalemia and its correction is not necessary for effective potassium repletion.
  • • Option B. Hypocalcemia:
  • • Option C. Hypermagnesemia: Hypermagnesemia (high magnesium) is rare and usually occurs in the setting of renal failure or excessive magnesium intake. It is not a common finding in alcoholism.
  • • Option C. Hypermagnesemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the association between chronic alcoholism and hypomagnesemia, which often coexists with hypokalemia. Understanding this relationship is crucial for effective treatment, as magnesium repletion is often necessary for successful potassium replacement in these patients.

questions.text: In CKD, the remaining nephrons undergo hyperfiltration and hypertrophy to compensate for lost renal mass. Which of the following is a long-term consequence of these adaptations?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glomerulosclerosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Improved renal function: Hyperfiltration and hypertrophy only temporarily maintain GFR and eventually lead to decline.
  • • Option A. Improved renal function:
  • • Option C. Increased renal blood flow: While blood flow initially increases, it eventually decreases as nephrons are lost.
  • • Option C. Increased renal blood flow:
  • • Option D. Decreased intrarenal pressure: Intrarenal pressure actually increases due to hyperfiltration, contributing to damage
  • • Option D. Decreased intrarenal pressure:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand that while hyperfiltration and hypertrophy are initially compensatory mechanisms in chronic kidney disease (CKD), they ultimately lead to glomerulosclerosis and progressive decline in renal function. Recognizing this pathophysiological process highlights the importance of early intervention and management to slow down the progression of CKD.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a 10-year history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with fatigue, edema, and hypertension. Laboratory tests reveal proteinuria and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 40 mL/min/1.73m2. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her chronic kidney disease (CKD)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lupus nephritis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Diabetic nephropathy : Diabetic nephropathy is not associated with SLE.
  • • Option A. Diabetic nephropathy
  • • Option B. Hypertensive nephrosclerosis : While hypertension can contribute to CKD, it's less likely to be the primary cause in a young patient with SLE.
  • • Option B. Hypertensive nephrosclerosis
  • • Option D. IgA nephropathy : IgA nephropathy typically presents with recurrent hematuria, not the constellation of symptoms seen here.
  • • Option D. IgA nephropathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize lupus nephritis as a common and potentially serious complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Early detection and management are crucial to preventing the progression of lupus nephritis to chronic kidney disease (CKD) and end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cardiovascular disease (CVD) in chronic kidney disease (CKD) is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: CVD is the leading cause of death in patients with CKD.

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of CVD decreases as CKD progresses.

options.label: C
options.text: Traditional CVD risk factors are not important in CKD patients.

options.label: D
options.text: Early-stage CKD patients do not require CVD screening.

questions.correct_answer: A. CVD is the leading cause of death in patients with CKD.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CVD is the leading cause of death in patients with CKD.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. The risk of CVD decreases as CKD progresses : The risk of CVD increases as CKD progresses.
  • • Option B. The risk of CVD decreases as CKD progresses
  • • Option C. Traditional CVD risk factors are not important in CKD patients : Traditional CVD risk factors are important, but CKD-specific risk factors must also be considered.
  • • Option C. Traditional CVD risk factors are not important in CKD patients
  • • Option D. Early-stage CKD patients do not require CVD screening : Early CVD screening and prevention are crucial in CKD patients.
  • • Option D. Early-stage CKD patients do not require CVD screening

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the significant impact of cardiovascular disease (CVD) on patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). It is crucial to recognize that CVD is the leading cause of death in this population and that the risk increases as CKD progresses. This knowledge highlights the importance of early CVD screening and aggressive management of both traditional and CKD-specific risk factors to improve outcomes for patients with CKD.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a GFR of 50 mL/min/1.73m² and an albuminuria level of 150 mg/g. According to the KDIGO 2012 classification, what is the patient's CKD stage?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the KDIGO 2012 classification, CKD staging is determined by both GFR levels and albuminuria categories. With a GFR of 50 mL/min/1.73m², this patient falls into the G3a category (45-59 mL/min/1.73m²), which represents "mildly to moderately decreased" kidney function. The albuminuria level of 150 mg/g places the patient in the A2 category (30-300 mg/g), representing "moderately increased" albuminuria. Together, these values classify the patient as G3aA2.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) G2A2 - This is incorrect because while the albuminuria category (A2) is appropriate, the GFR of 50 mL/min/1.73m² does not fall into G2 range, which is 60-89 mL/min/1.73m².
  • • Option A) G2A2
  • • Option C) G3bA2 - This is incorrect because G3b represents a GFR range of 30-44 mL/min/1.73m². The patient's GFR of 50 mL/min/1.73m² is higher than this range and falls into G3a instead.
  • • Option C) G3bA2
  • • Option D) G4A2 - This is incorrect because G4 represents a GFR range of 15-29 mL/min/1.73m², indicating severely decreased kidney function. The patient's GFR of 50 mL/min/1.73m² is substantially higher and does not indicate this level of severity.
  • • Option D) G4A2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The KDIGO 2012 classification system evaluates CKD by incorporating both GFR and albuminuria levels, providing a more comprehensive assessment of kidney disease severity and progression risk than GFR alone.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical finding in uremic pericarditis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Elevated troponin levels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Pericardial friction rub , Option B. PR depression on ECG and Option D. Diffuse ST-segment elevation on ECG : These are classic findings in uremic pericarditis.
  • • Option A. Pericardial friction rub
  • • Option B. PR depression on ECG
  • • Option D.
  • • Diffuse ST-segment elevation on ECG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the typical findings in uremic pericarditis, including pericardial friction rub, PR depression on ECG, and diffuse ST-segment elevation on ECG. It is important to recognize that elevated troponin levels are not a typical finding in uremic pericarditis, as it is not associated with myocardial damage.

questions.text: A patient with CKD stage 5 presents with asterixis, pericarditis, and platelet dysfunction. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Uremic toxin accumulation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Elevated BUN and creatinine : BUN and creatinine are markers of kidney function but don't directly cause these specific symptoms.
  • • Option A. Elevated BUN and creatinine
  • • Option B. Hyperphosphatemia : Hyperphosphatemia is a complication of CKD but is not the primary cause of these symptoms.
  • • Option B. Hyperphosphatemia
  • • Option D. Metabolic acidosis : Metabolic acidosis can contribute to uremic symptoms but is not the sole cause of these specific findings.
  • • Option D. Metabolic acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the classic manifestations of uremia, such as asterixis, pericarditis, and platelet dysfunction. These symptoms are caused by the accumulation of uremic toxins in the body due to severely impaired kidney function. Understanding this pathophysiology is crucial for early diagnosis and management of uremia in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with stage 4 CKD presents with fatigue and dyspnea on exertion. His hemoglobin level is 9.5 g/dL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his anemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Decreased erythropoietin production

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency and Option D. folate deficiency : Can also cause anemia, but they are less common causes of anemia in CKD. These deficiencies can be ruled out with blood tests.
  • • Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • • Option D. folate deficiency
  • • Option B. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency can contribute to anemia in some patients with CKD, but it is not the primary cause. Iron stores are usually assessed before starting treatment for anemia in CKD.
  • • Option B. Iron deficiency:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand that the primary cause of anemia in chronic kidney disease (CKD) is decreased erythropoietin (EPO) production due to kidney damage. This knowledge is essential for the accurate diagnosis and management of anemia in CKD patients, as it guides the choice of treatment, which often involves administering erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (ESAs) to compensate for the lack of endogenous EPO.

questions.text: Which of the following medications directly suppresses PTH secretion in CKD patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Calcitriol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Calcium carbonate : Calcium carbonate is a phosphate binder, not a PTH suppressant.
  • • Option A. Calcium carbonate
  • • Option B. Sevelamer : Sevelamer is a phosphate binder, not a PTH suppressant.
  • • Option B. Sevelamer
  • • Option C. Cinacalcet : Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic that increases the sensitivity of the parathyroid gland to calcium, indirectly lowering PTH
  • • Option C. Cinacalcet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the different classes of medications used to manage secondary hyperparathyroidism in chronic kidney disease (CKD), and to recognize that calcitriol is the only medication listed that directly suppresses parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion.

questions.text: A patient with CKD stage 3 has a PTH level of 150 pg/mL and a normal serum calcium level. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: No treatment is necessary at this time

questions.correct_answer: A. No treatment is necessary at this time
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) No treatment is necessary at this time

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Initiate calcium carbonate , Option C. Initiate calcitriol and Option D. Initiate cinacalcet : These medications are not indicated unless PTH levels exceed the target range or there are other complications of CKD-MBD.
  • • Option B. Initiate calcium carbonate
  • • Option C. Initiate calcitriol
  • • Option D.
  • • Initiate
  • • cinacalcet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand that not all elevated PTH levels in CKD require immediate intervention. Treatment decisions should be based on the severity of PTH elevation, calcium levels, and the presence of other complications of CKD-mineral bone disease (CKD-MBD).

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with kidney failure on dialysis develops a rapidly progressing, painful nodule on her abdomen that breaks down and forms an open sore (see image). She takes medications for high blood pressure (losartan) and blood clots (warfarin). Which of the following is LEAST likely about her condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Warfarin use is a risk factor.

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas infection is common.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Calcium supplements may worsen it: True. Calcium-based phosphate binders and vitamin D analogs can contribute to the development of calciphylaxis.
  • • Option A. Calcium supplements may worsen it:
  • • Option B. Calcium supplements may worsen it: True. Calciphylaxis is characterized by calcification of small blood vessels leading to ischemia and necrosis.
  • • Option B. Calcium supplements may worsen it:
  • • Option D. Warfarin use is a risk factor: True. Warfarin is associated with an increased risk of calciphylaxis.
  • • Option D. Warfarin use is a risk factor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the key features and risk factors associated with calciphylaxis, a rare but severe complication of chronic kidney disease (CKD). It is important to recognize that while Pseudomonas infection can occur in any open wound, it is not the most common pathogen associated with calciphylaxis. Staphylococcus aureus is more frequently implicated in these infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common presenting symptom in patients with ADPKD?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Flank or back pain

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Hypertension : Hypertension is common but may not be the initial presenting symptom.
  • • Option A. Hypertension
  • • Option C. Gross hematuria : Gross hematuria occurs in a significant proportion of patients but is less common than pain.
  • • Option C. Gross hematuria
  • • Option D. Urinary tract infection : Urinary tract infections are a complication but not the most common initial presentation.
  • • Option D. Urinary tract infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize that flank or back pain is the most common presenting symptom in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). This pain is often due to cyst enlargement, hemorrhage, or infection and may be the first sign of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is FDA-approved for slowing kidney disease progression in ADPKD?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tolvaptan

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Everolimus : Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor under investigation but not FDA-approved for ADPKD.
  • • Option B. Everolimus
  • • Option C. Octreotide : Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue with potential benefits but not FDA-approved.
  • • Option C. Octreotide
  • • Option D. Cinacalcet : Cinacalcet is used to treat secondary hyperparathyroidism in CKD
  • • Option D.
  • • Cinacalcet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand that tolvaptan is the only FDA-approved medication for slowing the progression of kidney disease in ADPKD. It works by inhibiting vasopressin, which plays a role in cyst growth.

questions.text: A 62-year-old end-stage renal disease (ESRD) patient requires hemodialysis access. Given the need for long-term vascular access, which arteriovenous fistula (AVF) would be the most suitable choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Radiocephalic AVF

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Brachiocephalic AVF and Option C. Brachiobasilic AVF : Larger vessels, higher flow, risk of steal syndrome/heart failure.
  • • Option A. Brachiocephalic AVF
  • • Option C. Brachiobasilic AVF
  • • Option D. Femoral AVF : Higher infection risk, deeper cannulation
  • • Option D. Femoral AVF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the importance of choosing the most suitable arteriovenous fistula (AVF) for long-term hemodialysis access. The radiocephalic AVF at the wrist is generally preferred due to its lower complication rates, easier cannulation, and preservation of future access sites.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a determinant of hemodialysis efficiency?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Patient's age

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Blood flow rate: Higher blood flow rates allow for greater clearance of solutes from the bloodstream across the dialyzer membrane.
  • • Option A. Blood flow rate:
  • • Option B. Dialysate flow rate: Faster dialysate flow rates create a steeper concentration gradient between the blood and dialysate, enhancing the diffusion of solutes from the blood into the dialysate.
  • • Option B. Dialysate flow rate:
  • • Option C. Dialyzer characteristics: The dialyzer membrane's surface area, porosity, and permeability all influence how effectively solutes are removed from the blood. For instance, a larger surface area allows for more clearance of solutes.
  • • Option C. Dialyzer characteristics:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the key factors that determine hemodialysis efficiency, including blood flow rate, dialysate flow rate, and dialyzer characteristics. While a patient's age can influence their overall dialysis needs, it doesn't directly affect the efficiency of the hemodialysis process itself.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is NOT typically associated with peritonitis in peritoneal dialysis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypotension

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cloudy dialysate, Option B. Abdominal pain and Option C. Fever : Cloudy dialysate, abdominal pain, and fever are classic signs of peritonitis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Cloudy dialysate, Option B. Abdominal pain
  • • Option C. Fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the typical clinical presentation of peritonitis in peritoneal dialysis, including cloudy dialysate, abdominal pain, and fever. Recognizing these signs and symptoms is crucial for early diagnosis and treatment to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with end-stage renal disease and uremia starts hemodialysis. During the session, he becomes restless, confused, and develops a headache. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Acute intradialytic hypotension: This would typically cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting, but not the neurologic symptoms described.
  • • Option A. Acute intradialytic hypotension:
  • • Option B. Hemodialysis-associated thrombosis: This would cause issues with the dialysis access site (e.g., pain, swelling, decreased blood flow) rather than neurologic symptoms.
  • • Option B. Hemodialysis-associated thrombosis:
  • • Option D. Air embolism during hemodialysis: This is a rare but serious complication that would present with sudden respiratory distress, chest pain, and potentially cardiac arrest.
  • • Option D. Air embolism during hemodialysis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the signs and symptoms of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS), a complication that can occur during the initial stages of hemodialysis in patients with uremia. DDS is caused by the rapid removal of urea, creating an osmotic gradient that leads to cerebral edema and neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A patient with secondary hyperparathyroidism due to end-stage renal disease undergoes a successful parathyroidectomy. During their first hemodialysis session post-surgery, which of the following dialysate modifications would be most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased calcium concentration

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Increased potassium concentration : Not relevant to HBS management. Potassium levels may need to be adjusted based on the patient's serum potassium.
  • • Option A. Increased potassium
  • • concentration
  • • Option B. Decreased potassium concentration : This could worsen hypokalemia, which is not a primary concern in HBS.
  • • Option B. Decreased potassium
  • • concentration
  • • Option D. Decreased calcium concentration : This would exacerbate the existing hypocalcemia in HBS and should be avoided
  • • Option D. Decreased calcium concentration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the importance of modifying dialysate calcium concentration after parathyroidectomy in patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism due to end-stage renal disease. Increasing the calcium concentration helps prevent severe hypocalcemia and its associated complications, known as "hungry bone syndrome" (HBS).

questions.text: Which of the following immunosuppressive medications binds to CD80 and CD86 on antigen-presenting cells, inhibiting T-cell activation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Belatacept

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Sirolimus: Sirolimus (rapamycin) is an mTOR inhibitor. It works by forming a complex with FKBP-12, which then binds to and inhibits the mTOR protein, thus blocking T-cell proliferation.
  • • Option A. Sirolimus:
  • • Option B. Everolimus: Everolimus is also an mTOR inhibitor and has a similar mechanism of action to sirolimus.
  • • Option B. Everolimus:
  • • Option D. Basiliximab: Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to the IL-2 receptor on activated T cells, preventing their proliferation.
  • • Option D. Basiliximab:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand the different mechanisms of action of immunosuppressive medications used in transplantation. Belatacept is unique in its ability to specifically inhibit T-cell activation by blocking the interaction between CD80/CD86 on antigen-presenting cells and CD28 on T cells.

questions.text: A 48-year-old kidney transplant recipient, 3 weeks post-transplant, presents with a sudden rise in serum creatinine, decreased urine output, and tenderness over the allograft. Doppler ultrasound shows increased renal artery resistance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute T-cell mediated rejection

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN): ATN usually occurs immediately post-transplant and is less likely weeks later. It would not typically cause allograft tenderness or increased arterial resistance on Doppler.
  • • Option A. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN):
  • • Option B. Calcineurin inhibitor toxicity: While this can cause elevated creatinine, it usually presents with more gradual onset and less specific symptoms.
  • • Option B. Calcineurin inhibitor toxicity:
  • • Option D. Antibody-mediated rejection: This is less likely to occur early post-transplant and typically presents with more severe features like glomerulitis and vascular injury on biopsy.
  • • Option D. Antibody-mediated rejection:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the clinical presentation and diagnostic findings of acute T-cell mediated rejection in kidney transplant recipients. This type of rejection typically occurs early post-transplant and presents with a sudden rise in creatinine, decreased urine output, allograft tenderness, and increased renal artery resistance on Doppler ultrasound. Differentiating this from other causes of graft dysfunction is crucial for prompt and appropriate intervention.

questions.text: A kidney transplant recipient with a positive CMV IgG serostatus develops fever, leukopenia, and elevated liver enzymes 4 months post-transplant. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm CMV infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CMV PCR

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Blood culture : Blood culture is not useful for diagnosing viral infections like CMV.
  • • Option A. Blood culture
  • • Option C. Liver biopsy : Liver biopsy is invasive and not typically needed for diagnosing CMV infection.
  • • Option C. Liver biopsy
  • • Option D. Lung biopsy : Lung biopsy is not indicated in this scenario as the primary organ involvement is not the lungs.
  • • Option D. Lung biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand that CMV PCR is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing CMV infection in transplant recipients, allowing for early detection and treatment to prevent complications.

questions.text: A kidney transplant recipient presents 3 months post-transplant with fever, dry cough, and shortness of breath. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and the drug of choice for its prophylaxis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) – Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) – Valganciclovir : Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common infection after transplantation, but it usually presents with nonspecific symptoms like fever and fatigue, and it does not typically cause the classic chest X-ray findings of PJP. Valganciclovir is used for CMV prophylaxis and treatment.
  • • Option A. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) – Valganciclovir
  • • Option C. Aspergillus fumigatus – Fluconazole : Aspergillus fumigatus is a mold infection that can cause pulmonary symptoms, but it is less common in the early post-transplant period. Fluconazole is an antifungal medication, not used for PJP prophylaxis.
  • • Option C. Aspergillus fumigatus – Fluconazole
  • • Option D. Nocardia asteroides – Ganciclovir : Nocardia asteroides is a bacterial infection that can cause pulmonary or disseminated disease, but it is less common than PJP in this setting. Ganciclovir is used for CMV prophylaxis and treatment
  • • Option D. Nocardia asteroides – Ganciclovir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To recognize the clinical presentation and chest X-ray findings of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) in kidney transplant recipients and to understand that trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the preferred prophylactic agent for PJP.

questions.text: Which of the following is the leading cause of death in kidney transplant recipients?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cardiovascular events

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Infection: While infection is a significant cause of mortality in transplant recipients (18%), it is not as common as cardiovascular events.
  • • Option A. Infection:
  • • Option B. Malignancy : Malignancy, including PTLD, is also a concern for transplant recipients (17%), but it is still less common than cardiovascular events.
  • • Option B.
  • • Malignancy
  • • Option D. Graft failure: While graft failure can lead to death, it is not as frequent a cause as cardiovascular events.
  • • Option D. Graft failure:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ To understand that cardiovascular events are the leading cause of death in kidney transplant recipients, highlighting the importance of cardiovascular risk assessment and management in this population.
